label: def-algorithmic-cemetery-extension
name: Algorithmic Cemetery Extension
natural_language_statement: The algorithmic space is extended to include a 'cemetery' point, denoted by a dagger, which represents the state of a dead walker. The distance from any valid point in the original space to this cemetery point is defined as a constant.
description: This definition formalizes the concept of a 'dead' walker by extending the metric space of walker states. By adding a unique cemetery point, we can canonically define the distance to a swarm of dead walkers (the cemetery law), which simplifies the analysis of swarm death and stability. The Wasserstein distance between any living swarm and the cemetery law becomes a fixed constant.
formal_statement: Define the extended space $\mathcal{Y}^{\dagger} := \mathcal{Y} \cup \{\dagger\}$ with a metric $d_\dagger$ such that for $y_1, y_2 \in \mathcal{Y}$, $d_\dagger(y_1, y_2) = d_{\mathcal{Y}}(y_1, y_2)$, and for any $y \in \mathcal{Y}$, $d_\dagger(y, \dagger) = D_{\mathrm{valid}}$.

relations.description: The p-Wasserstein distance between the law of any living swarm, Î½, and the cemetery law (a Dirac measure at the cemetery point), is equal to the constant $D_{\mathrm{valid}}$.
